story.kicker_image_caption: This will make you want to throw away your bag. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/alicia
story.storykicker: Your handbag's residents have got company; some very nasty company!
story.storybody:
There are so many things that live inside your handbag. Apart from perfumes bottles, moisturisers, make-up, cash and coins, there are a thousands nasty bacteria that keep your things company.

According to a study by Queen Mary University, fecal bacteria is present on 26 per cent of hands in the UK, 14 per cent of banknotes and 10 per cent of credit cards.

And your hands, banknotes and credit cards all end up in your bag eventually. Right?
 
If that isn't bad enough, tests carried out by Initial Washroom Hygiene in 2013 found that an old bottle of hand cream in a handbag contains more bacteria than the average toilet.

Also read: Global Handwashing Day: Wash away the myths around handwashing

The UK study also revealed that the bag's handle is a bacteria hotspot, and the stuff inside the bag, like makeup or cream, has toilet-flush levels of bacteria.

According to Charles Gerba, a University of Arizona microbiologist who has studied bacteria living on handbags, "About a third of them have fecal bacteria on them."
story.magazinekicker: Your handbag's residents have got company; some very nasty company!
story.shortheadline: Did you know that your handbag is dirtier than an average toilet seat?
